abstractText: The Avadānaśataka is an ancient collection of Buddhist legends, its first redaction dating to the first centuries of the CE. It was translated into Chinese and Tibetan during the first millennium CE, gaining large popularity across Asia. This Nepalese incomplete palm-leaf manuscript contains the beginning of the Dharmapālāvadāna, the thirty-third story in the collection. These two folios are part of a bundle of nine folios possibly from four different manuscripts, containing parts of five stories from the Avadānaśataka. They were used by Speyer for his edition of the Avadānaśataka and were given the siglum F.

title: Avadānaśataka
